customData.content: 47-year-old male presented to the emergency department with persistent nonradiating pain in the right hypochondrium, nausea, anorexia, early satiety, and an 11-kg weight loss over 1 month. Past medical history includes heavy smoking, severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and previous intravenous drug use. Physical examination revealed painful hepatomegaly. Laboratory values demonstrated microcytic normochromic anemia (Hb 7.2 g/dL), elevated alkaline phosphatase (254 U/L), and elevated gamma-glutamyl transferase (287 U/L).

HPI.summary: 47-year-old male presented with persistent nonradiating pain in the right hypochondrium, nausea, anorexia, early satiety, and an 11-kg weight loss over 1 month.

customData.content: Abdominal ultrasound showed an enlarged and diffusely nodular liver. Thoraco-abdominopelvic CT demonstrated a 2-cm nodule in the inferior lobe of the left lung and signs of diffuse hepatic metastases. Upper endoscopy revealed a 1-cm ulcerated nodular lesion in the greater curvature of the gastric body. Biopsies demonstrated submucosal infiltration of small hyperchromatic cells with scant cytoplasm.

imaging.finding: 2-cm nodule in the inferior lobe of the left lung and signs of diffuse hepatic metastases

procedures.name: Upper endoscopy
procedures.outcome: 1-cm ulcerated nodular lesion in the greater curvature of the gastric body

procedures.name: Biopsy
procedures.outcome: submucosal infiltration of small hyperchromatic cells with scant cytoplasm

customData.content: Immunohistochemistry of gastric lesion revealed diffuse immunoreactivity to CAM5.2, synaptophysin, and chromogranin, compatible with gastric infiltration of neoplastic cells with neuroendocrine differentiation. Liver biopsy showed similar histology. Bronchoalveolar lavage cytology and bronchial biopsy revealed TTF-1-positive cells with similar expression of neuroendocrine markers, confirming small cell lung cancer (SCLC).

imaging.finding: TTF-1-positive cells with similar expression of neuroendocrine markers, confirming small cell lung cancer (SCLC)

customData.content: Diagnosis of stage IV small cell lung cancer (SCLC) established. CT scan showed a 2-cm nodular lesion in the upper segment of the inferior lobe of the left lung and a 3.7 x 2.4 cm infracarinal adenomegaly. Hepatomegaly and diffuse hepatic metastases present. Nodular lesion with central ulceration in the greater curvature in the body of the stomach.

imaging.finding: 2-cm nodular lesion in the upper segment of the inferior lobe of the left lung
imaging.impression: stage IV small cell lung cancer (SCLC)
stage IV small cell lung cancer (SCLC)

imaging.finding: Hepatomegaly and diffuse hepatic metastases present
imaging.impression: stage IV small cell lung cancer (SCLC)

imaging.finding: Nodular lesion with central ulceration in the greater curvature in the body of the stomach
imaging.impression: stage IV small cell lung cancer (SCLC)

customData.content: Gastric submucosal infiltration of hyperchromatic small neoplastic cells (H&E, ×20). Liver biopsy demonstrating severe infiltration of liver parenchyma by neoplastic cells, with frequent figures of mitosis (arrow) and apoptosis. Liver biopsy demonstrating immunohistochemical expression of chromogranin neoplastic cells. Occurrence of nonspecific upper gastrointestinal symptoms with red flag signs prompted an endoscopic evaluation.

imaging.finding: nonspecific upper gastrointestinal symptoms with red flag signs
imaging.impression: nonspecific upper gastrointestinal symptoms with red flag signs

labs.value: severe infiltration of liver parenchyma by neoplastic cells, with frequent figures of mitosis and apoptosis
immunohistochemical expression of chromogranin neoplastic cells

customData.content: Neuroendocrine markers chromogranin and synaptophysin strongly positive in gastric lesion, suggesting gastric involvement by a neuroendocrine neoplasm, later confirmed as a SCLC metastasis. Patient's functional status rapidly deteriorated, and he died 3 months after the diagnosis.

data.content: Patient underwent abdominal ultrasound, thoraco-abdominopelvic CT, and upper endoscopy with biopsies to investigate the cause of right hypochondrium pain, nausea, anorexia, early satiety, and weight loss.
Immunohistochemistry of gastric lesion and liver biopsy performed to determine the type and origin of the cancer.
Diagnosis of stage IV small cell lung cancer (SCLC) established based on imaging and biopsy results.
Palliative chemotherapy initiated to treat stage IV small cell lung cancer (SCLC).
Occurrence of nonspecific upper gastrointestinal symptoms with red flag signs prompted an endoscopic evaluation.

Neuroendocrine markers chromogranin and synaptophysin strongly positive in gastric lesion, suggesting gastric involvement by a neuroendocrine neoplasm, later confirmed as a SCLC metastasis. Patient's functional status rapidly deteriorated, and he died 3 months after the diagnosis.
